title: Business coalition hits Canberra with competition communique
text:
John Osborn Director of Economics & Industry Policy at ACCI said the changes to competition policy would benefit big and small businesses
Master Grocers Australia has rallied as many as 20 industry groups to descend on Canberra next week in an attempt to convince the government to back the introduction of an effects test into competition law.
It's the first time this broad coalition, including representatives from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the National Farmers Federation has joined forces to agitate for policy change.
Participants claim the group speaks for the vast swathe of small and medium sized businesses in Australia that want the government to adopt the recommendations of the Harper competition review, including the fortification of section 46.
The recommendations from Ian Harper's Competition Policy Review panel included changes to the competition law to target any activity with the "purpose or likely effect of substantially lessening competition."
Advertisement Master Grocers Australia's Jos de Bruin said he believed there was public support for the introduction of an effects test.
He said the meeting in Canberra was an opportunity to frame the benefits of the proposed change, particularly the positive impact on productivity and innovation.
"What we don't want is for the voice of a few to get in the way of something that is good for Australia," Mr de Bruin said.
"Let's get ahead and not go back to what we had, which was cosy for big business and left very little certainty for anyone else."
Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry's John Osborn said this was not a David and Goliath battle between big and small business.
"This is about competition reform that benefits small and big business alike," Mr Osborn said.
"There's growing consensus this will be a reasonable change that will be good for consumers and good for business."
Mr Osborn said he was confident the group would get the opportunity to put their argument to Mr Turnbull.
"The new prime minister and treasurer have already demonstrated their willingness to be consultative and...we are confident we will get a hearing on the effects test and competition reform," Mr Osborn said.
The big retailers are fighting hard through the Business Council of Australia to prevent the introduction of an effects test, which was all but shelved by the former prime Minister Tony Abbott.
BCA chair Jennifer Westacott, who is also a Wesfarmers director has allegedly called on the chiefs of the big business lobby's membership to speak out against the proposed changes.
Mr Turnbull put the so called effects test back on the agenda when he made it a key plank of the coalition agreement with The Nationals.
But Turnbull only committed to take the changes to section 46 back to cabinet and it's not clear how quickly this will happen.
Responsibility for competition policy has also been excised from the small business portfolio, and added to the Treasurer Scott Morrison's workload.
Advocates of the effects test are keen to get a clear read on the Prime Minister's position on competition policy but they are also working hard to keep the conversation open and transparent.
Council of Small Business Australia 's outspoken chief Peter Strong said the government needed to "resist the silly arguments" against the effects test, including claims by the BCA it would lead to increased prices.
"This is about the consumer and if we get more competition prices will drop," Mr Strong said.
"We've said that the government can't meet with the big end of town and not meet with the representatives from small to medium sized businesses."
